German

[edit]

Alternative forms

[edit]
  • schmeissen (Switzerland, Liechtenstein; often also Luxembourg, South Tyrol)

Etymology

[edit]

From Middle High German smƒ´zen, from Old High German smƒ´zan, from Proto-West Germanic *smƒ´tan, from Proto-Germanic *smƒ´tanƒÖ, from Proto-Indo-European *smeyd-.

Cognate with Dutch smijten, Low German smieten, English smite, Danish smide, Gothic êå±êåπêçÉêåºêå¥êåπêçÑêå∞êåΩ (bismeitan).

Verb

[edit]

schmei√üen (class 1 strong, third-person singular present schmei√üt, past tense schmiss, past participle geschmissen, auxiliary haben) (informal)

  1. (transitive or intransitive, often figurative) to throw; to fling; to hurl [with accusative or mit (+ dative) ‚Äòsomething‚Äô, along with auf (+ accusative) ‚Äòonto/at someone/something‚Äô or in (+ accusative) ‚Äòinto someone/something‚Äô]
    die Schule schmei√üen ‚Äï to drop out of school
    Er schmiss seine Tasche aufs Bett. ‚Äï He flung his bag on the bed.
    Sie schmei√üt mit Kastanien auf die anderen Kinder.
    She‚Äôs throwing chestnuts at the other children.
    Schmei√ü das in den M√ºlleimer! ‚Äï Throw that in the trashcan!
    Ich schmiss mich ins Bett, weil ich so m√ºde war.
    I threw myself into bed because I was so tired.
    Du schmei√üt Geld aus dem Fenster.
    You're wasting money.
    (literally, ‚ÄúYou're throwing money out the window.‚Äù)
  2. (transitive, informal) to drop accidentally
    Pass auf, dass du die Flasche nicht auf den Boden schmei√üt.
    Watch out, don't drop the bottle on the ground.
  3. (transitive, colloquial) to manage; to organize; to run
    Ich muss hier heut den ganzen Laden alleine schmei√üen.
    I have to run this whole thing on my own today.
    Ich schmei√üe meine Gesch√§fte und du deine.
    I'll run my business and you run yours.
    Den Haushalt zu schmei√üen ist schwieriger, als es aussieht.
    Running the household is harder than it looks.
  4. (transitive, theater) to flub (a scene), to corpse
    eine Szene schmei√üen ‚Äï to flub a scene
  5. (transitive, colloquial) to pay for (a round of drinks)
    eine Runde schmei√üen ‚Äï to pay a round
  6. (transitive, slang) synonym of einschmei√üen; to swallow (drugs)
    • 2020, Katharina K√∂ller, Was ich im Wasser sah‎[1], Frankfurter Verlagsanstalt, ‚ÜíISBN:
      Ich hatte Karten gespielt, Geld verloren, einmal einen kleinen Affen gewonnen, der mir sofort davongelaufen war, mich betrunken, mich bekifft, Partydrogen geschmissen [‚Ä¶]
      (please add an English translation of this quotation)
    • 2021 July 15, Thomas Abeltshauser, ‚ÄúFilm √ºber p√§dosexuellen Missbrauch: Wenn das alte Leben zerst√∂rt ist‚Äù, in Die Tageszeitung: taz‎[2], ‚ÜíISSN:
      Er feiert exzessiv, in den Clubs der Stadt, wo er kokst und Pillen schmei√üt und forsch sehr junge M√§dchen aufrei√üt.
      (please add an English translation of this quotation)
  7. (intransitive, obsolete or hunting, chiefly of animals) to defecate

Usage notes

[edit]
  • All usage of this verb is considered informal to some degree.
  • There are more colloquial expressions using it, ranging from the figurative to the idiomatic, than are listed here, so the above meanings should be regarded as a representative sample.
